message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of white deposits in the brain during prenatal check and blue dots on the baby along with the absence of object tracking suggest congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection. Sensorineural hearing loss is a common symptom of congenital CMV infection. The other options are not associated with congenital CMV infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The white deposits seen on prenatal ultrasound may indicate a congenital infection such as cytomegalovirus, which can cause sensorineural hearing loss. The blue dots all over the baby may be indicative of a condition known as Mongolian spot, which is a common benign finding in darker-skinned infants and should not cause any additional concerns. A continuous machine-like murmur would suggest a congenital heart defect, but there is no other indication of this in the scenario. Hutchinson teeth and skin vesicles are also unrelated to the symptoms presented.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clue here is the presence of blue dots, which suggests the possibility of congenital rubella syndrome. Sensorineural hearing loss is a common feature of this syndrome, as well as cataracts and cardiac defects. Continuous machine-like murmur (PDA), Hutchinson teeth (syphilis), and skin vesicles (herpes) are not associated with congenital rubella.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of white deposits in the brain during prenatal check and blueness at birth suggest possible congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection. Sensorineural hearing loss is the most common sequela. A continuous machine-like murmur is associated with patent ductus arteriosus, which is not related to the symptoms. Hutchinson teeth are related to congenital syphilis, which is not the likely diagnosis here. Skin vesicles are associated with herpes simplex virus, which is not the likely diagnosis either.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of object tracking suggests a possible hearing loss. The presence of blue dots all over the baby's body during birth may suggest Mongolian spots, which are benign and usually resolved on their own. Continuous machine-like murmur suggests patent ductus arteriosus, which is unlikely given the unremarkable physical exam. Hutchinson teeth and skin vesicles are not related to the baby's presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of object tracking may suggest impaired vision, while the blue dots all over suggest the presence of Mongolian spots which are common in infants with darker skin. The prenatal ultrasound findings may suggest the presence of calcifications which are commonly seen in cases of congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection. Sensorineural hearing loss is a common manifestation of congenital CMV infection and occurs in up to 12% of affected infants. The other options do not fit with the clinical presentation.

We refer to the Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics for help. The presence of white deposits in the brain and blue dots on the skin suggest the possibility of congenital infection, like congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection. Sensorineural hearing loss is a common consequence of congenital CMV infection, and absence of object tracking is another clinical feature of congenital CMV. Continuous machine-like murmur may occur in a different congenital heart defect called patent ductus arteriosus. Hutchinson teeth and skin vesicles are signs of congenital syphilis, another possible cause of congenital infections.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of blue dots suggests the possibility of a genetic disorder such as neurofibromatosis type 1, which can cause sensorineural hearing loss. A machine-like murmur may suggest a heart defect, Hutchinson teeth are associated with congenital syphilis, and skin vesicles may suggest a viral infection, but none of these match the symptoms described in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of object tracking and the prenatal finding of "white deposits in his brain" suggest a possible diagnosis of congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection. Sensorineural hearing loss is a common complication of congenital CMV infection, while continuous machine-like murmur suggests patent ductus arteriosus, Hutchinson teeth suggests congenital syphilis, and skin vesicles suggest herpes simplex virus infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The baby’s history suggests that he may have congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection, which can cause microcephaly, hearing loss, and chorioretinitis. Absence of object tracking is a sign of visual impairment, which may be caused by chorioretinitis. A continuous machine-like murmur is a sign of patent ductus arterial and may be present in premature infants, but it is not specifically associated with CMV infection. Hutchinson teeth are characteristic of congenital syphilis, which is not suggested by this history. Skin vesicles are not a common feature of CMV infection.
